questions.text: A research team is examining the regulation of fetal hemoglobin expression and the gene product involved in its down regulation. They have primary tissue cultures from fetal, neonatal, and adult liver and bone marrow, along with a DNA probe for the gene of interest. To determine the gene's expression levels in these tissue culture samples, which method is most appropriate?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Northern blot.

 

Option B:

 

  • In a Northern blot → all the mRNA from a cell type is electrophoresed on a gel → blotted onto the nitrocellulose → the DNA probe is applied and hybridized → excess is washed off → final resultant blot is autoradiographed. 

  • Bands on the autoradiograph film indicate the mRNAs contains sequences complementary to the probe → Shows the gene on the probe has been expressed in the mRNA of that cell. 

  • This is the best technique for determining whether a gene is expressed in a particular cell type.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: DNA sequencing and Option D: Southern blot: These techniques examine the DNA of the cell and the DNA of all the cells involved is identical.

 

Option C: Polymerase chain reaction (PCR): It is used to amplify DNA and cannot determine which tissue culture has expressed the gene being studied. It also amplifies the DNA probe which is necessary for Northern blotting. However, in this case, the DNA probe was supplied in adequate amounts → therefore PCR is not recommended.

 

Educational objective:

 

Northern blotting is the correct method for determining the expression of a specific gene. It measures mRNA levels, which correlate directly with gene expression. This technique involves the separation of RNA by gel electrophoresis, transfer to a membrane, and hybridization with a labelled probe specific to the mRNA of interest.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 456-457.

questions.text: Given the DNA template shown, with regions A, B, C, and D, which pair of primers should be used to effectively amplify this region through PCR?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) B and C

 

Option A:

 

  • For a PCR experiment, primers are important that will allow DNA synthesis to occur across the region of DNA to be amplified.

  • As DNA polymerase always synthesizes DNA in the 5’ to 3’ direction, the 3’ ends of the primers must face each other and bracket the region of DNA to be amplified.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B, Option C, Option D: Primers Option A and Option D will only allow DNA synthesis away in the opposite direction from the region of interest, due to their orientation on the DNA template strand.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When designing primers for PCR amplification, it is important to select primer pairs that are complementary to the 3' ends of opposite strands of the target DNA region. This ensures that the DNA polymerase can successfully amplify the entire region between the primers.

 

Ref: Vasudevan 9/e: p 658.

choices.text: Restriction Endonuclease cuts the DNA at the defective sequence
Artificially created chromosomes can’t be used as a vector
Helpful in study of molecular basis of a disease
DNA to be cloned is called as Chimeric DNA

questions.text: A molecular biology lab in India is exploring various technologies to understand the genetic basis of a rare disease. Among the discussed technologies, which of the following statements is TRUE?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Helpful in study of molecular basis of a disease            

 

Option C:

 

  • The molecular biology technology is RECOMBINANT DNA TECHNOLOGY
  • Restriction Endonuclease cuts the DNA at specific palindromic sequence, which is a sequence of duplex DNA that is the same when the two strands are read in opposite directions. e.g. GATCC and CCTAG (Option (A).
  • VECTORS: Plasmids, Cosmides ,Phages & artificially created chromosomes (Option (B)
  • Uses of Recombinant DNA Technology in Clinical Medicine
  • To study the molecular basis of a disease by expressing the defective gene causing this disease and studying its function by expression in E. coli (Option C)
  • Preparation of vaccines and hormones
  • Diagnosis of infectious diseases

 

Forensic medicine— to identify a criminal from specimens left on the crime scene.

 

  • DNA to be cloned + Vector DNA = Chimeric DNA or recombinant DNA (Option (d)

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Restriction Endonuclease cuts the DNA at the defective sequence: Cut the DNA at specific palindromic sequence.

 

Option B. Artificially created chromosomes can’t be used as a vector: Can be used as a vector.

 

Option D. DNA to be cloned is called as Chimeric DNA: DNA to be cloned + Vector DNA = Chimeric DNA or recombinant DNA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Molecular biology technologies are instrumental in dissecting the molecular basis of diseases. These tools allow researchers to delve into genetic mutations, expression patterns, and interactions that underpin disease processes, thereby contributing significantly to medical science's understanding and treatment strategies.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 452-454

questions.text: Following a positive ELISA screening test for HIV, a patient undergoes a confirmatory Western blot test. For this assay, which component is specifically separated using polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis before being transferred to a membrane for detection?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) HIV proteins

 

Option D:

 

The HIV tests are looking for the presence of antibodies in the patients sera against HIV proteins. So, in the confirming western blot, HIV proteins are separated by size on a polyacrylamide gel, the proteins transferred to filter, and the filter paper treated with sera sample. If the sera contains antibodies to HIV proteins, they will bind to the proteins on the filter paper and the presence of antibodies on the filter paper is then detected using secondary antibodies.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Patient sera and Option B: Patient plasma: While these are used in the test, they are not separated by the gel. Instead, antibodies in the sera or plasma react with the HIV proteins on the membrane.

 

Option C: HIV RNA: This would not be used in a Western blot, which is a protein-detection method. HIV RNA could be detected using techniques like RT-PCR, not Western blot.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a Western blot test for HIV, the components that are separated using polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis and then transferred to a membrane for detection are HIV proteins. These proteins are detected by their reaction with antibodies in the patient's serum, confirming the presence of an HIV infection.

 

Ref: Vasudevan 9/e: 736.

questions.text: Match the following techniques with the appropriate disorders:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1-c, 2-d, 3-a, 4-b

 

Option D:

 

Explanation:

 

  1. Recombinant DNA Technology: It is widely used for the antenatal diagnosis of genetic diseases by identifying gene mutations or creating transgenic models.

  2. PCR: PCR is a cornerstone in the diagnosis of bacterial and viral diseases due to its ability to amplify specific DNA sequences, making pathogen detection more sensitive.

  3. FISH: Fluorescence In Situ Hybridization (FISH) is a technique used to detect and localize the presence or absence of specific DNA sequences on chromosomes. It's commonly used for the detection of numerical abnormalities of chromosomes.

  4. Gene therapy: This technique is applied in the treatment of diseases, including cancer, by introducing, altering, or replacing genes within an individual's cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Vasudevan 9/e: p 654-661.

questions.text: During a forensic investigation of a sexual assault case, the crime scene investigators have procured a semen sample and tissue samples from the victim. They have also obtained DNA samples from the victim and three suspects for analysis. To compare the variable number of tandem repeats (VNTR) among these samples, which technique is most suitable for the initial analysis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Southern blot

 

Option C:

 

  • A VNTR analysis examines the hypervariable regions of the human genome.

  • These contain sequences that are repeated in tandem for a variable number of times and its length is unique for everyone.

  • As it is a DNA fragment being analyzed, Southern blot is the best technique to separate and detect these regions.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. DNA sequencing: Though it can detect DNA similarities but It is expensive and time-consuming for forensic analysis. It can be used for a confirmatory analysis.

 

Option B. Northern blot: It is used to separate and detect RNA.

 

Option D. Western blot: It is used for detection of proteins.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Southern blot is the best technique for the initial analysis in this context, as it is used for DNA analysis, specifically to detect certain sequences within a DNA sample by using restriction enzymes and a DNA probe. This method is well-suited for VNTR analysis, which is a type of polymorphism that can be highly variable among individuals and is useful for forensic DNA typing.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e:  p 456-457.

questions.text: At her 27-week prenatal check-up in a Mumbai healthcare clinic, a pregnant woman receives a rubella vaccine. Subsequently, her body develops anti-rubella antibodies. This immune response involves a specific genetic mechanism fundamental to antibody diversity in humans. Which mechanism underlies the formation of these antibodies in the body?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gene rearrangement  

 

Option A:

 

  • The process by which immunoglobulins (antibodies) are produced by B lymphocytes involves permanent rearrangements of the DNA in these cells.
  • The immunoglobulins (e.g. - IgG) consist of two light and two heavy chains, with each chain containing regions of variable and constant amino acid sequence.
  • The variable region is the result of somatic recombination of segments within both the light- and the heavy-chain genes.
  • During B-lymphocyte development, single variable (V), diversity (D), and joining (J) gene segments are brought together through gene rearrangement to form a unique variable region.
  • This process allows the generation of different immunoglobulins from a single gene, providing the diversity needed for the recognition of an enormous number of antigens.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Gene amplification: This is a mechanism by which gene expression is increased thousandfold. E.g: Methotrexate (anticancer drug)- works by this mechanism.

 

Option C. Alternate splicing: Tissue-specific protein isoforms can be made from the same pre-mRNA through differential co-transcriptional processing, especially the use of alternative splice sites. e.g: Tropomyosin (TM), its pre-mRNA undergoes tissue-specific differential splicing to yield different TM isoforms.

 

Option D. RNA interference: It is a mechanism of gene silencing with decreased expression of mRNA, either by repression of translation or by increased degradation.  E.g: It plays a key role in fundamental processes as cell proliferation, differentiation, and apoptosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gene rearrangement is the process responsible for the formation of antibodies in the body. This mechanism involves the reorganization of variable (V), diversity (D), and joining (J) gene segments in B cells. This recombination leads to a vast diversity of antibodies, enabling the immune system to recognize a wide array of antigens, such as those presented by the rubella virus following vaccination.

 

Ref: Lippincott 7/e: P 461.

questions.text: A research team is utilizing various laboratory techniques to quantify the concentration of DNA samples extracted from patient biopsies. They are considering the most appropriate method that would provide accurate, rapid, and non-destructive analysis. Which of the following instruments is best suited for the quantitative analysis of DNA in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) UV spectrometer

 

Explanation:

 

A UV spectrometer (or spectrophotometer) is the standard and most widely used instrument for the rapid, non-destructive quantification of DNA.

 

DNA strongly absorbs ultraviolet light at a wavelength of 260 nm due to its nucleotide bases. Using Beer-Lambert’s law, the absorbance at this wavelength can be directly related to the DNA concentration:

 

This method is:

  • Fast
  • Non-destructive
  • Accurate for pure DNA samples.

 

In contrast to other methods, it does not require dyes, gels, or amplification, making it ideal for direct concentration measurement.

 

Other Options:

  • Option A. Gel electrophoresis:
    Useful for qualitative analysis (e.g., DNA size, integrity) but not as accurate for quantification. It is also destructive, and staining agents like ethidium bromide are needed.
  • Option C) Light microscope: Incorrect.
    A light microscope is used to visualize cells or large cell structures, not molecules like DNA, and cannot provide concentration data.
  • Option D) PCR machine: Incorrect.
    PCR (Polymerase Chain Reaction) is designed to amplify specific DNA sequences, not for direct DNA quantification. Quantitative PCR (qPCR) can estimate copy numbers of specific targets, but not general DNA concentration before the amplification process.

 

Educational Objective (Polished):


DNA can be accurately quantified using UV spectrophotometry at 260 nm, exploiting the strong absorbance of nucleic acid bases. This method is non-destructive, fast, and reliable, and is widely used before downstream applications like PCR, cloning, or sequencing.

 

Ref: Vasudevan 9/e: 744.

choices.text: Translocations with no loss of genetic element

questions.text: A family with multiple genetic disorders in different members underwent genetic counselling and genetic testing as shown. Which chromosomal anomaly is least likely to be detected by this method, as given in the picture?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Translocations with no loss of genetic element 

 

Option C:

 

The depicted technique is a microarray, which is excellent for identifying variations in copy number but does not detect balanced translocations where there is no loss or gain of genetic material.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Copy number variations: The microarray can detect CNVs, as they result in different signal intensities compared to normal copy numbers.

 

Option B: Microdeletion: Microdeletions, which are losses of small DNA segments, cause a reduced signal and are detectable with this microarray technique.

 

Option D: Amplification: DNA amplifications lead to an increased signal on the microarray and can be easily identified by this method.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Microarray CGH (Comparative genomic hybridization)

 

  • Detect Gene Amplification

  • Detect Gene Deletion

  • Detect copy number variations

  • But array CGH will not detect a balanced translocation, without loss of genetic elements as both normal and diseased sample will show no difference in amount of probe attachment and signal amplification.

 

Ref: Lippincott 7/e: P 483-484.

questions.text: A researcher at a genetics laboratory is analyzing a gel-based technique for DNA analysis. The process includes the separation of DNA fragments by electrophoresis, transfer of the DNA from the gel to a nitrocellulose sheet, and identification using a labelled DNA probe. What is the molecular biology technique depicted in the image?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Southern Blotting – DNA                      

 

Option B:

 

  • The below picture illustrates the Southern (DNA), Northern (RNA), and Western (protein) blot transfer procedures.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Southern Blotting - RNA: Laboratory technique used to detect a specific DNA sequence in the blood and tissue sample.

 

Option C: Northern Blotting - Protein: Molecular biology technique to study gene expression by detection of RNA in a sample.

 

Option D: Western Blotting -DNA Protein Interaction: Molecular biology technique to study individual proteins in a sample.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The technique shown in the image is Southern Blotting, which is used for DNA detection. The process involves the separation of DNA fragments by agarose gel electrophoresis, transfer of DNA onto a nitrocellulose or nylon membrane, and hybridization with a labelled DNA probe, which is then visualized through autoradiography. The presence of "32 P-labelled DNA probe" in the image confirms that the target for detection is DNA, not RNA or protein.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e page 456-457.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a history of diabetes mellitus is admitted to the surgical ICU of a tertiary care hospital in India for the management of a severe diabetic foot ulcer. During his stay, the medical team notes an increase in staphylococcal infections among patients in the unit. To investigate the source and control the outbreak, the infection control team decides to use molecular techniques to identify the strains of Staphylococcus causing these infections. They opt for the RFLP technique to differentiate between the species of staphylococci present in the ICU. Based on your understanding of RFLP, which of the following statements is FALSE regarding this technique?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Recognizes trinucleotide repeats

 

Option B:

 

These repeats are usually not part of a palindromic site and also do not affect the number of palindromic sites. So, a RFLP analysis will most probably not be able to detect these types of variations. A better method to detect these types of mutations/variations will be FISH analysis.

 

Two type of DNA Variations that can give rise to RFLP are:

 

  1. Single Nucleotide Polymorphism (SNP)
  2. Variable Number Tandem Repeat (VNTR)

 

Uses of RFLP

 

  • Tracing chromosomes from parent to offspring.
  • Prenatal diagnosis of phenylketonuria
  • Diagnosis of sickle cell disease
  • Medicolegal uses
  • Detects mutations, point mutation, insertion, deletion.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Detects mutation & Option C: Detects deletion - Both can give rise to RFLP and can be detected by RFLP analysis.

 

Option D: Blunt ends are produced: The restriction endonucleases enzymes used for RFLP analysis can either produce blunt end DNA or sticky end DNA depending on the type of enzyme used.

 

Educational Objective:

 

RFLP is a technique used to detect variations in DNA sequences by using restriction enzymes to cut DNA at specific sequences, and then analysing the pattern of resulting fragments. This method is effective for identifying point mutations and deletions that alter restriction sites but is not specifically designed to recognize trinucleotide repeat expansions, which are better analysed using PCR or Southern blot techniques.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e page 463.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents to a healthcare facility with a fever, cough, and shortness of breath. Given the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, the medical team decides to test for SARS-CoV-2. Which of the following diagnostic methods is NOT typically used for the direct detection of SARS-CoV-2?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Southern blotting

 

Option C:

 

  • As SARS is an RNA virus, Northern blotting technique can be used for the diagnosis but not southern blotting which detects DNA.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: RT-PCR: True. Reverse Transcription Polymerase Chain Reaction (RT-PCR) is a widely used method for detecting SARS-CoV-2 RNA by converting RNA into DNA, amplifying it, and then detecting it, making it a standard diagnostic tool for COVID-19.

 

Option B: Real-time PCR: True. Real-time PCR, a variant of PCR, allows for the monitoring of the reaction as it occurs, and is used for the quantitative detection of SARS-CoV-2 RNA, making it another key tool in COVID-19 diagnostics.

 

Option D: Immunoassays: True. Immunoassays, which can include tests like ELISA or rapid antigen tests, detect the presence of viral proteins (antigens) or host antibodies against the virus, and are used in the diagnosis and surveillance of COVID-19, although they have different applications and sensitivities compared to PCR-based methods.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Southern blotting is a molecular biology technique used to detect specific DNA sequences in DNA samples, not typically used for the direct detection of viral RNA, such as that of SARS-CoV-2. This method involves transferring DNA from a gel to a membrane followed by hybridization with a labeled probe, but it is not suitable for the rapid, sensitive detection of viral RNA necessary for diagnosing acute viral infections like COVID-19.

 

Ref: Vasudevan 9/e: p 658.

questions.text: A physician studied the global patterns of gene expression in two different types of tumour cells, so he can develop the most appropriate form of chemotherapy for each patient. Which of the following techniques will be most appropriate for this purpose?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Microarray

 

Option A:

 

  • Microarray analysis is used to determine the messenger RNA (mRNA) production (gene expression) from thousands of genes at once.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Northern blot: Measures mRNA production from one gene at a time.

 

Option C: Southern blot: Used to analyze DNA, but not the DNA expression.

 

Option D: Western blot: Measure protein production and gene expression but only from one gene at a time.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Microarray is the most appropriate technique for studying global patterns of gene expression. This technology allows simultaneous analysis of the expression levels of thousands of genes, providing a comprehensive overview that is essential for comparing different tumor types and informing personalized chemotherapy treatments.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e:  p 465-466.

questions.text: A lab technician is preparing a reaction mix for Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) and must add a divalent cation essential for the enzymatic activity of DNA polymerase. Which of the following ions should be included in the PCR mix?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mg++

 

Option B:

 

  • PCR helps in the synthesis of millions of copies of a specific nucleotide sequence in a few hours.
  • Magnesium ion (Mg2+) functions as a cofactor for activity of DNA polymerases by enabling incorporation of dNTPs during polymerization.
  • The magnesium ions at the enzymes active site catalyse phosphodiester bond formation between the 3’-OH of a primer and the phosphate group of a dNTP.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Calcium ions (Ca++) are not typically used in PCR reactions.

 

Option C: Lithium ions (Li+) are not a component of standard PCR reaction mixes.

 

Option D: Sodium ions (Na+) are not the necessary divalent cation for DNA polymerase activity in PCR.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Magnesium ions (Mg++) are critical cofactors for DNA polymerase enzymes used in PCR. They act by stabilizing the DNA polymerase and aiding in the binding of nucleotides to the DNA template.

 

Ref: Tietz Textbook of Clinical Chemistry 4/e page 1446.

questions.text: A molecular biologist is working on isolating a specific gene within a large DNA fragment ranging from 50 to 100 kilobases (KB) in length. Which technique is most suitable for this purpose?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Chromosome walking

 

Option D:

 

Chromosome walking is a technique used to isolate and map genes within large DNA molecules. It involves sequentially cloning contiguous segments of DNA to progressively move toward a gene of interest, making it ideal for isolating genes within 50-100 KB DNA fragments.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Notch: This term does not refer to a molecular biology technique for isolating genes.

 

Option B: RFLP (Restriction Fragment Length Polymorphism): While RFLP is used for identifying differences in homologous DNA sequences, it is not specifically used for isolating long genes.

 

Option C: SSLP (Simple Sequence Length Polymorphism): This technique is used for genetic mapping and not for the isolation of long DNA sequences.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chromosome Walking

 

  • It is the method to isolate and clone target DNA from a long segment of DNA.
  • In Chromosome walking, a fragment representing one end of a long piece of DNA is used to isolate another fragment which overlaps the first but extends the first and this process is continued till the target DNA is isolated.
  • Cystic fibrosis (CF) gene was the first to be isolated by chromosome walking.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e page 463.

questions.text: A forensic scientist is explaining the basis of DNA fingerprinting technology during a workshop. DNA fingerprinting relies on the analysis of which type of DNA sequences?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Variable Number Tandem Repeat

 

Option B:

 

DNA fingerprinting primarily utilizes Variable Number Tandem Repeats (VNTRs), which are sequences that repeat a variable number of times in the genome. The number of repeats varies significantly among individuals, making VNTRs highly useful for identification purposes in forensic science, paternity testing, and genetic diversity studies.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Constant Tandem Repeats do not provide the variability needed for DNA fingerprinting.

 

Option C: Non-repetitive sequences are less useful for DNA fingerprinting because they do not offer the same level of individual variability as VNTRs.

 

Option D: Exons, which are the coding regions of genes, are not typically used in DNA fingerprinting due to their relative conservation across individuals compared to VNTRs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DNA Fingerprinting/ DNA Profiling:

 

  • The use of normal genetic variation in the DNA (SNP or VNTR or RFLP) to establish a unique pattern of DNA fragments for an individual.
  • Most commonly used: VNTR or repeat length polymorphism.
  • Primer is needed for the processing.

 

Ref: Vasudevan 9/e: p 657

choices.text: Can diagnose Cri du chat disease
Can be used to detect molecular defects eg: point mutation
Unknown chromosomal anomaly can be detected

questions.text: A clinical laboratory employs a cytogenetic technique to visualize chromosomes, aiding in the diagnosis of genetic diseases and anomalies. Given the utility of this technique in various clinical scenarios, which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the capabilities of the cytogenetic technique displayed in the image?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Can be used to detect molecular defects eg: point mutation

 

The image provided is a karyotype using spectral karyotyping (SKY). This advanced method uses fluorescent probes to paint each chromosome in different colors, making it easier to identify chromosomal abnormalities such as deletions, translocations, and duplications. however, it is not typically used to find molecular-level defects (point mutation), which often require genomic sequencing or other high-resolution molecular methods.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Can diagnose Cri du chat disease - CORRECT statement. 

Cri du chat syndrome results from a deletion on the short arm of chromosome 5, which would be visible as a structural abnormality on chromosome 5 (light blue in this image). This technique can detect such large chromosomal deletions.

 

Option B. Can diagnose Philadelphia chromosome - CORRECT statement.

The Philadelphia chromosome is a reciprocal translocation between chromosomes 9 and 22, which would appear as chromosomes with two different colors in the karyotype. This technique can detect such translocations.

 

Option D. Unknown chromosomal anomaly can be detected - CORRECT statement. This technique is designed to identify both numerical (extra or missing chromosomes) and structural (translocations, deletions, duplications) chromosomal abnormalities, even those that haven't been previously characterized.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cytogenetic techniques like spectral karyotyping detect large structural chromosome abnormalities, not molecular-level mutations like point mutation.

 

Ref: Vasudevan 9/e: p 655.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient with cystic fibrosis has prompted his family members to seek genetic counselling. They were advised to undergo testing for common mutations associated with the disease. The brother's DNA was extracted, and the regions of interest in the CFTR gene were amplified using PCR. The DNA polymerase enzyme used in PCR is highly resistant to which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Heat

 

Option D:

 

  • Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) technique uses heat to separate the double stranded DNA, so that each strand can be used as templates for new DNA synthesis. 
  • The DNA polymerase of bacteria which grows in hot springs (Thermus aquaticus) is highly stable at high temperatures and is widely used for PCR reactions.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Acid: False. DNA polymerase's resistance is not typically characterized by acid resistance, but by its ability to withstand the heat used to denature the DNA strands during PCR.

 

Option B: Base: False. Like acid resistance, base resistance is not a standard characteristic used to describe DNA polymerase in the context of PCR.

 

Option C: High Na+ concentration: False. The resistance of DNA polymerase to high sodium ion concentrations is not a key feature; its heat resistance is more relevant to its function in PCR.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The DNA polymerase used in the Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) technique is typically Taq polymerase, which is derived from the thermophilic bacterium Thermus aquaticus. This enzyme is known for its resistance to heat, which allows it to remain stable and functional during the high-temperature denaturation steps of the PCR cycle.

 

Ref: Vasudevan 9/e: p 658.

choices.text: True, QF-PCR is inappropriate for aneuploidy detection due to a lack of quantitative accuracy.
False, QF-PCR is well-suited for aneuploidy detection as it quantitatively amplifies chromosome-specific sequences.
True, QF-PCR is only qualitative and cannot differentiate between normal and abnormal chromosome numbers.
False, QF-PCR cannot be used to amplify DNA sequences from chromosomes prone to aneuploidies.

questions.text: In the context of prenatal diagnosis, a geneticist discusses the use of various molecular techniques to detect chromosomal abnormalities. Which of the following statements regarding the suitability of Quantitative Fluorescent PCR (QF-PCR) for detecting aneuploidies is accurate?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) False, QF-PCR is well-suited for aneuploidy detection as it quantitatively amplifies chromosome-specific sequences.

 

Option B:

 

QF-PCR is indeed appropriate for the detection of aneuploidies. This technique involves amplifying short tandem repeat (STR) markers specific to the chromosomes of interest, using fluorescently labeled primers. The amplified products are then analyzed to determine the number of repeats, which corresponds to the number of chromosome copies, thereby detecting aneuploidy.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: This statement is incorrect because QF-PCR is known for its quantitative precision, which is essential for detecting aneuploidy.

 

Option C: This statement is incorrect as QF-PCR is a quantitative method that can accurately determine the copy number of chromosomes, distinguishing between aneuploid and euploid samples.

 

Option D: This statement is incorrect because QF-PCR can and is used to amplify DNA sequences from chromosomes, especially those that are commonly involved in aneuploid conditions such as Down syndrome (trisomy 21), Edwards syndrome (trisomy 18), and Patau syndrome (trisomy 13).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Methods to detect aneuploidy

 

  • Conventional Karyotyping
  • FISH
  • Microarray based CGH
  • Multiple Ligation dependent Probe Amplification (MLPA)
  • Real time PCR
  • Quantitative Fluorescent PCR (QF–PCR)
  • Multiplex amplifiable probe hybridization (MAPH).

 

Ref: Vasudevan 9/e: p 658.

choices.text: Cut DNA at specific DNA sequences.
To point out the coding regions

questions.text: A molecular biologist is explaining the role of endonucleases in DNA manipulation during a seminar. What is the primary function of endonucleases?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cut DNA at specific DNA sequence.

 

Option A:

 

  • Restriction endonuclease cut DNA at specific palindromic sites.
  • These enzymes are isolated from bacteria.
  • They restrict the entry of Phages into the bacteria.
  • They are widely used in various molecular biology techniques such as RFLP, Genetic engineering etc.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Endonucleases do not have the function of identifying coding regions; this is determined through gene annotation processes.

 

Option C: Enhancers are regulatory DNA sequences, not enzymes, and are involved in increasing the transcription of certain genes.

 

Option D: The determination of antibiotic resistance is usually done through phenotypic assays or by identifying specific resistance genes, not directly by endonucleases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Endonucleases are enzymes that recognize and cut DNA at specific nucleotide sequences. This cutting can occur within the length of the DNA molecule, unlike exonucleases, which remove nucleotides from the ends of DNA.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e page 453.

choices.text: Replacement of abnormal gene by normal gene
Replacement of normal gene by abnormal gene

questions.text: During a discussion on advanced treatments for genetic disorders, a medical researcher explains the primary goal of gene therapy. What is the main purpose of gene therapy?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Replacement of abnormal gene by normal gene.

 

Option A:

 

The primary goal of gene therapy is to treat genetic disorders by replacing an abnormal (mutated) gene with a functional (normal) gene. This can help correct or mitigate the effects of the genetic disorder by restoring the normal function of the gene.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: The replacement of a normal gene with an abnormal gene is not a therapeutic strategy and would likely lead to disease.

 

Option C: While gene knockout techniques are used in research to study gene function, the primary goal of therapeutic gene therapy is often to add a functional gene rather than to knock out the abnormal gene.

 

Option D: The introduction of a viral gene is a method used in gene therapy to deliver the therapeutic gene into the patient's cells, but the ultimate goal is not to introduce viral genes per se, but to use viral vectors to introduce therapeutic genes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Gene Therapy is the intracellular delivery of genes to produce a therapeutic effect by correcting an existing abnormality.
  • It is divided into:
  1. Somatic cell gene therapy - Gene is introduced into somatic cells.
  2. Germ cell gene therapy (Transgenic animal).

 

Ref: Vasudevan 9/e: p 648.

choices.text: Thermostable at temperature at which DNA liquefies

questions.text: A molecular biology student is learning about the Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) and questions why DNA polymerase from Thermus aquaticus (Taq) is preferred over E. coli DNA polymerase. What is the primary reason for this preference?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Thermostable at temperature at which DNA liquefies

 

Option A:

 

The primary reason for preferring Taq DNA polymerase from Thermus aquaticus in PCR is its thermostability. Taq polymerase can withstand the high temperatures required for DNA denaturation in PCR cycles, unlike E. coli DNA polymerase, which denatures at these temperatures.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Proofreading capability: While proofreading is an important feature for some applications, Taq polymerase is actually known for lacking 3' to 5' exonuclease proofreading activity, which some other polymerases possess.

 

Option C: Operates more precisely: Precision in PCR is more a function of the reaction conditions and primer design than the choice of polymerase. Taq is chosen for its thermostability, not necessarily for increased precision.

 

Option D: Does not require a primer: All DNA polymerases, including Taq, require primers to initiate DNA synthesis. This is not a distinguishing feature of Taq polymerase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In the polymerization step of PCR, new DNA strands are synthesised by the enzyme Taq polymerase, which is derived from bacteria Thermus Acquaticus that are found in hot springs.
  • Hence, the enzyme is not denatured even at high temperature.
  • The polymerase reaction takes place at 72°C for 30 seconds in presence of dNTPs (all four deoxyribonucleotide triphosphates).
  • All E. coli DNA pol can only work at room temperature.

 

Ref: Vasudevan 9/e: p 658.
